sentences.text: Central Texas Bernie, WAKE UP!!! This is the 21st century, we are chasing 'Tacticals', with armored vehicles, in Iraq and Afghanistan, with slow progress, and lots of wounded, to show for our 'High tech' approach to an almost archaic adversary! HOW, I gotta ask, are you gonna reconcile two completely different approaches to law, in a short time? The UCMJ is an oxymoron, of the highest level, like "Military Intelligence"! It is anything but uniform, in that, if your daddy was a West Pointer, different rules apply, and, say you got Gohnorrea (sp?) as an officer, it was "non specific uretheritis", but, as an enlisted man, an "STD", requireing altogether different (Read this, an Art 15 proceeding) legal handling! Should question the "J" word, consider that exercising your first amendment right to freedom of speech, in the military, easily could net you the same results, or worse.

sentences.text: Here, in Texas, the use of Lethal Force falls under our Penal code, and, to summarize, is justified to prevent the commission of a Felony, or, when one is met with such force as a reasonable person might judge to be able to cause severe bodily harm, or death, to himself, or another.

sentences.text: When "Polite Society" begins to realize that their lives are made better by the absence of 'Bad Actors', through the process of mortality, not only will the "gun control" bills, and speeches, be reduced, but so will local taxes, since the courts will have less costly cases to try! My personal feeling is that a weapon ought to be like a kiss; for special moments, which neither of us can ever forget! If you ever have occasion to see my personal weapons, there are but two options, since I am a sensitive kind of guy; Cease resistance, or, Die.

sentences.text: Are we going to sanction governmental interference in our private lives to the degree that some bureaucratic body can determine what constitutes adequate security for a car, a firearm, a long-handled shovel, a carving knife, a baseball bat, all of which can and not infrequently have been used to murder innocents? sentences.ctext: Every honest gun owner has also altered the fingerprint of every gun he or she has ever fired.

sentences.text: Let me explain how that works.

sentences.ctext: Let me explain how that works.

sentences.text: The idea behind "ballistic fingerprinting" is this: a fired case has unique marks from the extractor, ejector, and breechface.
sentences.mtext: The=the=DT=0 idea=idea=NN=1 behind=behind=IN=2 "="=``=3 ballistic=ballistic=JJ=4 fingerprinting=fingerprint=VBG=5 "="=''=6 is=be=VBZ=7 this=this=DT=8 :=:=:=9 a=a=DT=10 fired=fire=VBN=11 case=case=NN=12 has=have=VBZ=13 unique=unique=JJ=14 marks=mark=NNS=15 from=from=IN=16 the=the=DT=17 extractor=extractor=NN=18 ,=,=,=19 ejector=ejector=NN=20 ,=,=,=21 and=and=CC=22 breechface=breechface=NNS=23 .=.=SENT=24
sentences.ctext: The idea behind "ballistic fingerprinting" is this: a fired case has unique marks from the extractor, ejector, and breechface.

sentences.text: A bullet fired through a barrel also has unique rifling marks.

sentences.ctext: A bullet fired through a barrel also has unique rifling marks.

sentences.text: If you store the information in a central database, you theoretically could link a firearm back to the owner.
sentences.mtext: If=if=IN=0 you=you=PP=1 store=store=VBP=2 the=the=DT=3 information=information=NN=4 in=in=IN=5 a=a=DT=6 central=central=JJ=7 database=database=NN=8 ,=,=,=9 you=you=PP=10 theoretically=theoretically=RB=11 could=could=MD=12 link=link=VB=13 a=a=DT=14 firearm=firearm=NN=15 back=back=RB=16 to=to=TO=17 the=the=DT=18 owner=owner=NN=19 .=.=SENT=20
sentences.ctext: If you store the information in a central database, you theoretically could link a firearm back to the owner.

sentences.text: (I say "theoretically" because, to date, none of the ballistic databases has been instrumental in solving any actual crime.)
sentences.mtext: (=(=(=0 I=I=PP=1 say=say=VBP=2 "="=``=3 theoretically=theoretically=RB=4 "="=''=5 because=because=IN=6 ,=,=,=7 to=to=TO=8 date=date=NN=9 ,=,=,=10 none=none=NN=11 of=of=IN=12 the=the=DT=13 ballistic=ballistic=JJ=14 databases=database=NNS=15 has=have=VBZ=16 been=be=VBN=17 instrumental=instrumental=JJ=18 in=in=IN=19 solving=solve=VBG=20 any=any=DT=21 actual=actual=JJ=22 crime=crime=NN=23 .=.=SENT=24 )=)=)=25
sentences.ctext: (I say "theoretically" because, to date, none of the ballistic databases has been instrumental in solving any actual crime.)

sentences.text: A ballistic fingerprint is only a one-time snapshot of a gun.

sentences.ctext: A ballistic fingerprint is only a one-time snapshot of a gun.

sentences.text: Ejectors, extractors, and barrels all suffer wear through normal use, and all can (and should) be replaced at regular intervals.

sentences.ctext: Ejectors, extractors, and barrels all suffer wear through normal use, and all can (and should) be replaced at regular intervals.

sentences.text: Change one part, and the fingerprint is useless.

sentences.ctext: Change one part, and the fingerprint is useless.

sentences.ctext: But even absent this normal swapping of worn-out parts, every time a gun is fired, the fingerprint changes just a little bit.

sentences.text: New scratches appear; old ones are worn away.

sentences.ctext: New scratches appear; old ones are worn away.

sentences.ctext: As time goes on, the fingerprint is completely altered and the data in the files becomes useless.

sentences.text: That is why I say that every honest gun owner has altered the fingerprint of every gun he or she has ever fired, and that no law can be passed to prevent it from happening.

sentences.ctext: That is why I say that every honest gun owner has altered the fingerprint of every gun he or she has ever fired, and that no law can be passed to prevent it from happening.

sentences.text: Fact is, trying to track a single gun by this method is not like tracking people by their fingerprints.

sentences.ctext: Fact is, trying to track a single gun by this method is not like tracking people by their fingerprints.

sentences.text: It's more like to trying to ID someone by their hairstyle.

sentences.ctext: It's more like to trying to ID someone by their hairstyle.

sentences.text: It'll work for awhile, but the person can either deliberately disguise themselves by dyeing or cutting their hair, or the normal passage of time will lengthen their hair, turn it grey, or cause it to fall out entirely.

sentences.ctext: It'll work for awhile, but the person can either deliberately disguise themselves by dyeing or cutting their hair, or the normal passage of time will lengthen their hair, turn it grey, or cause it to fall out entirely.

sentences.text: Either which way, a hairstyle cannot be considered a reliable method of identifying an individual, because it changes over time.

sentences.ctext: Either which way, a hairstyle cannot be considered a reliable method of identifying an individual, because it changes over time.

sentences.text: And for the same reason, a ballistic fingerprint is not a reliable method of identifying a gun.

sentences.ctext: And for the same reason, a ballistic fingerprint is not a reliable method of identifying a gun.

sentences.text: But even if the ballistic fingerprint were akin to a fingerprint and not a hairstyle, it is still a relatively useless tool.

sentences.ctext: But even if the ballistic fingerprint were akin to a fingerprint and not a hairstyle, it is still a relatively useless tool.

sentences.ctext: Bullets can be severely deformed, or fragmented into several pieces.

sentences.ctext: This knocks out a huge swath of crime guns -- in New York, D.C., Chicago, and other big gun-control areas, almost all guns will be outside the system.

sentences.text: The benefit would be limited to a very narrow subset of all crimes: murders that involve guns, from which either an intact bullet or shell casing is recovered, and which crimes cannot be solved in any other fashion.

sentences.text: As has been pointed out already, the proposition that you need to know the particulars of another law-abiding citizen (as you put it) in order to make an informed decision about your own safety makes no sense.

sentences.text: None whatsoever.

sentences.text: Page 2 of 3 Are there unintended consequences to stricter gun control laws and the politically expedient path that we have started down? In a recent op-ed piece in the San Francisco Chronicle, Brett Joshpe stated that Gun advocates will be hard-pressed to explain why the average American citizen needs an assault weapon with a high-capacity magazine other than for recreational purposes.We agree with Kevin D. Williamson (National Review Online, December 28, 2012): The problem with this argument is that there is no legitimate exception to the Second Amendment right that excludes military-style weapons, because military-style weapons are precisely what the Second Amendment guarantees our right to keep and bear.

sentences.ctext: It is against sound policy for a free people to keep up large military establishments and standing armies in time of peace, both from the enormous expenses, with which they are attended, and the facile means, which they afford to ambitious and unprincipled rulers, to subvert the government, or trample upon the rights of the people.

sentences.text: The right of the citizens to keep and bear arms has justly been considered, as the palladium of the liberties of a republic; since it offers a strong moral check against the usurpation and arbitrary power of rulers; and will generally, even if these are successful in the first instance, enable the people to resist and triumph over them.

sentences.text: If there is a staggering legal precedent to protect our 2nd Amendment right to keep and bear arms and if stricter gun control laws are not likely to reduce gun related crime, why are we having this debate? Other than making us and our elected representatives feel better because we think that we are doing something to protect our children, these actions will have no effect and will only provide us with a false sense of security.

sentences.text: I agree with Kevin D. sentences.text: The right of the citizens to keep and bear arms has justly been considered, as the palladium of the liberties of a republic; since it offers a strong moral check against the usurpation and arbitrary power of rulers; and will generally, even if these are successful in the first instance, enable the people to resist and triumph over them.
